fields.description: Stash appears not to comply with the LifecycleAware contract as implemented in other applications. If a plugin exposes a LifecycleAware component, the {{onStart}} method gets called correctly during application startup; but if the plugin is stopped and started (either by disabling and re-enabling it, or by upgrading it to a new version), {{onStart}} is not called when the plugin is restarting. I've verified that this works correctly in the other Atlassian apps.
fields.summary: LifecycleAware component's onStart method is not called after plugin upgrade/enablement
All the sweet plugins.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of Jun 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Bitbucket Server 6.4 has built-in banner feature. Please read the docs to learn more about it - [Announcement banner|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/add-a-system-wide-announcement-banner-973479805.html]. 

!image.png|width=281,height=215!

Cheers,

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

It would be useful to have a freeform text area that you could enter text into - like the Unix / IRC Message Of The Day (MOTD).

This would appear in the(user home page, or in the header) show that new users could get a description of the installation, and it could be updated (infrequently) with new information for users such as upgrades, or upcoming maintenance downtime.

I would like to further refine this request to add a PRIORITY or (urgency) to the Message. So that a Message could be in the in the simplist iteration an INFORMATION (where the user can dismiss it if they choose to) or a WARNING where as they CANNOT dismiss it, and that it is HIGHLIGHTED (color?) to assure that user understands the importanncy or urgency of the information.
fields.summary: Announcement Banner

fields.description:
Since the advent of global receive hooks (2.0), Stash now relies on the existence of perl being available for git hooks.

See 2.0/receive hooks section in https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+Support+Resources

Update the following documents:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Installing+Stash+on+Windows
* Check git and perl at the same time - installation instructions are to install git properly

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Installing+Stash+on+Linux+and+Mac
* Check git and perl at same time, but direct them to get perl from http://www.perl.org/get.html or via their favourite package manager
fields.summary: Update install docs to include Perl check

fields.description:
In Markdown when you have consecutive lines separated by newline characters they should be treated as a single paragraph and therefore when rendered the newline characters inside a paragraph should be ignored.

The attached png shows the incorrect rendering of the Markdown README in one of my projects. If you would like further detail on this check out the explanation at the following:

http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#p

If you want an example to reproduce this, the difference can be easily seen by having two paragraphs one that is defined on multiple lines in the markdown file and another that is defined on a single line. I have provided an example of each of these below.

This is a paragraph that exists on multiple lines.
This is the second line of the paragraph.
This is the third line of the paragraph.
This is the fourth line of the paragraph.

This is a paragraph that exists on a single line. This is the second line of the paragraph. This is the third line of the paragraph. This is the fourth line of the paragraph.

*Note:* I listed *Repository - Source Page* as the associated component but I believe the issue is much more wide spread as even as I am making this ticket in Jira I am seeing the same issue. I believe the issue is probably in the Markdown parser that you guys are using and that the issue should be resolved there. However, I didn't see a component for the markdown parser so please adjust the ticket as needed.
fields.summary: Markdown README render is incorrectly including newline characters when rendering paragraphs.

fields.description: Just wondering if one of the two 2.0.0 zip archives on the [Source Downloads|https://my.atlassian.com/download/source/stash] page is meant to be for Stash 2.0.1.
fields.summary: Stash 2.0.1 source download missing?

fields.description:
The Gravatar URL used by Stash appears to always return a "default" image for some users.

My users have all created Gravatar accounts, however Stash still shows "white heads on grey" for everyone but me.  (The same is true for them, they only see _my_ avatar).  Here's an example of what the page looks like:

!white-on-grey.png!

This is the image URL generated by Stash: http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/ee194f150caf4ef175b36caaeb2f7782.jpg?s=48&d=mm

When I visit that, I get the "white head on grey".

If I manually remove the last bit of the query string {{&d=mm}}, then the correct image is shown:

http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/ee194f150caf4ef175b36caaeb2f7782.jpg?s=48 produces:

!avatar.png!

My avatar URL works even with the extra {{&d=mm}} parameter: http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/811bf781347cfb9f8d6c74e355a843d9.jpg?s=48&d=mm

I don't know if this is this your problem or Gravatars ...
fields.summary: Gravatar URL used by Stash appears to always return a "default" image.

fields.description:
At the present moment you are able to click on an image (jpg, gif, etc) and Stash will render this image. 

It would be nice if it could display .swf files instead of receiving a "This file cannot be rendered in your browser." message.
fields.summary: Add the ability to view .swf files in source view.

fields.description: As a head of development I want to see the last date of commits per repository on the overview page. That helps to monitor project activities. The granularity in terms of branches should be customizable.
fields.summary: Show Last Commit Information for each Repository

fields.description:
I tried to push into a Stash managed git repository from a plugin which failed with the following error showing up in the logs:

{code}
[WARNING] [talledLocalContainer] com.atlassian.stash.exception.ServerException: An error occurred while executing an external process: '/usr/local/bin/git push init master' exited with code 1 saying: remote: hooks/pre-receive: line 6: /Users/stefan/dev/atlassian-private/shpxxi-17/pages-plugin/target/stash/home/data/repositories/16/hooks/pre-receive.d: is a directory
[WARNING] [talledLocalContainer] remote: hooks/pre-receive: line 6: exec: /Users/stefan/dev/atlassian-private/shpxxi-17/pages-plugin/target/stash/home/data/repositories/16/hooks/pre-receive.d: cannot execute: Undefined error: 0
[WARNING] [talledLocalContainer] To /Users/stefan/dev/atlassian-private/shpxxi-17/pages-plugin/target/stash/home/data/repositories/16
{code}

This is due to the {{$STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR}} variable not being set in the {{pre-receive}} script.

{code}
exec $STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR hooks/pre-receive.d "$@" <&0 >&1 2>&2
{code}

While the failure itself is legitimate (we don't want users to push into the repo directly without executing the hooks), the error is misleading.

We should check whether the variable is actually set (e.g. {{if [ -z "$STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR" ];then ...}}) and print a better error message in that case.


We should also consider bolstering the bash scripts we "install" by requiring variables to be set via {{set -u}} (or the longer form {{set -o nounset}}).


Note: git version 1.7.12 (for posterity)
fields.summary: Improve error message for receive hooks when pushing into a git repository outside of Stash

fields.description:
After creating a new repository within Stash, and attempting the following via command line in an existing git repo:
{code}
git remote set-url origin file:///path/to/stash/home/data/repositories/12
git push --all
{code}

...the following error occurs:
{code}
remote: hooks/pre-receive: line 6: /path/to/stash/home/data/repositories/12/hooks/pre-receive.d: is a directory
remote: hooks/pre-receive: line 6: exec: /path/to/stash/home/data/repositories/12/hooks/pre-receive.d: cannot execute: Unknown error: 0
To /path/to/stash/home/data/repositories/12
 ! [remote rejected] master -> master (pre-receive hook declined)
error: failed to push some refs to '/path/to/stash/home/data/repositories/12'
{code}

Using a URL to the repository works, but I'm trying to understand why the pre-receive stage works for one and not the other?
fields.summary: pre-receive hook error when pushing to filesystem URL

fields.description:
In order to filter all pull request notifications from Stash keywords in the body needs to be included in the filter rule (e.g. "View pull request").

In order to make filtering and skimming a list of pull request emails easier it would be beneficial to add a subject prefix to email notifications (e.g. "[stash]" or "[pull request]").
fields.summary: Add a subject prefix to the pull request notification to make it easier to filter pull requests coming from Stash

fields.description: Stash assumes bash is located in /bin/bash. On platforms that do not ship with bash, such as FreeBSD, a bash port can be installed to another directory such as /usr/local/bin/bash. Stash should add support for non-standard locations for the bash executable.
fields.summary: Support non-standard location of Bash

fields.description:
We would like an option to comment on diffs in a pull request, but viewable first broken down by commit.

All of the pieces are effectively already there, because the pull request UI has a tab called 'Commits' which lets you see the commits that form the pull request.  These commits have links:

!see_commits.png!

However, when you click on a link, it takes you to a 'Commits' tab at a level in parallel with 'Pull requests':

!commits_tab.png!

... and you can't make comments at this point. :-(

We want to be able to comment on the individual change sets within a pull request, not just the pull request as a whole.

The reason is this:

A complex pull request can have changed a lot of files.  However, the individual commits within a pull request will (hopefully) have broken the changes into more intellectual digestible chunks.  By viewing the pull request as a series of commits, the reviewer gets to go on the same logical journal as the original author took (or, that the original author synthesised through rebasing prior to pushing).
fields.summary: Review and comment on pull request diffs, broken down first by commit.

fields.description:
In our workflow, whenever there is a pull request, the entire team (~5 members) takes part in a code review.  In Crucible (which we are abandoning in favour of Stash 2), it was possible to define the set of default reviewers so that it didn't have to be re-entered each time (and eliminates the possibility of forgetting to add someone).

We would like equivalent functionality in Stash.

This seems related to STASH-2870, which is said to duplicate STASH-2842.  However, I don't see that STASH-2842 necessarily covers the above.
fields.summary: Have a default set of reviewers

fields.description: Automatically detect and link JIRA keys from commit messages
fields.summary: Link JIRA keys in commit messages

fields.description: Would be nice to have a way to save reviewers as the default reviewers for a repository that apply to all users new or old for that repo. I'm always typing in the same set of people each time I do a pull request.
fields.summary: Default reviewers for a repository

I'm not sure where the bug is - could be in the git plugin for Jenkins, but I thought I'd start here since Atlassian is so responsive.

I'm evaluating stash 2.0.0 and we use Jenkins as our build automation tool.  We running the latest LTS versions of Jenkins (1.480.1) and the git plugin (1.1.26)

I'll attach some screenshots detailing the configuration and the problems.

fields.description:
The commit log shows timestamps in fuzzy format "1 week ago", which is fine, but there should be some way to see the exact time also.

A simple solution could be: hovering over the fuzzy time would show exact date & time.

The date & time, when shown, should be in a consistent time-zone. Very very needed for a cross-geography team.

Stash should notify whenever a newer version is available.

This could be shown to all users or just to the admin. (Prefer latter)

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of May 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5  | titleBGColor=#3C78B5  | bgColor=#E7F4FA  }
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Stash.

This suggestion is a priority for the Stash development team and is on our roadmap, however we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved.

Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,
Roger Barnes
Product Manager - Stash

{panel}
*Original request description:*

Forcing all merges to a certain branch (except for key people) to go via pull requests is currently possible in branch permissions.

Pull Requests give traceability and the option to comment on code being merged in - in addition, developers can use plugins and merge checks to add additional controls and warnings to the Pull Request page.

This means that automated checks can be added as merge checks and the people that can be allowed to merge is greater than those who can push - a pre-receive hook doesn't allow good feedback or warnings to the user (as well as not having the context of the branch being merged in, the author etc), so  allowing only a restricted set of users to push but allowing all to merge a pull request is desirable.
fields.summary: Allow merging via pull request but disallow pushing directly to branch

fields.description:
Event listeners for RepositoryPushEvent are no longer triggering in Stash 2.0. This worked fine as of 1.3.1 and, unless we can find a workaround, this is a major blocker for us in adopting Stash internally.

For a comparison I verified that RepositoryPullEvent listeners trigger in Stash 2.0, so the issue seems to be limited to push events specifically. (I'm guessing this might be related to changes for branch permissions).
fields.summary: RepositoryPushEvent not triggered in 2.0 when starting stash from AMPS

fields.description:
Not sure if this is the right place to report this, but when running atlas-create-stash-plugin the generated atlassian-plugin.xml contains the wrong path for the location for the JS resource.

<resource type="download" name="example.css" location="/css/example.css"/>
<resource type="download" name="example.js" location="/css/example.js"/>

Notice that the example.js resource has "/css/" as a prefix instead of "/js". Spent quite a bit of time on two occasions trying to figure out why JS was not loading.

It would be handy to have a 'show all' function, like in fisheye.

fields.description:
See this [comment|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2481?focusedCommentId=412648&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-412648] from another user for details on this feature.

Summary: If a user creates a branch under their username namespace, they automatically get full read/write/delete/rewind privileges to that branch.

For Example:

I make a branches: *davidrogers/featureX* or *p-davidrogers-featureX* (different orgs may have different naming conventions)

I can rebase/sync with the master branch, and do a non-fastforward push to davidrogers/featureX. On a long running personal feature branch, it's useful to sync up with master every once in a while.

fields.description:
I've installed Stash and initially used internal database. Later, when I wanted to migrate to MySQL (on /admin/db/edit page) I've faced 2 problems:

1. no MySQL driver pre-installed (both Confluence & Jira have that driver) and I needed to copy one from Jira installation

2. Message in red "Stash does not have adequate permissions to modify the target database using the nominated user. Please check that the user has permission to CREATE and DROP tables and INSERT and DELETE data from the database. For information about configuring databases for use with Stash, please refer to the Stash documentation." saying that I don't have right permission for database.

This is a bug, because I've used same db user (with another database of course) with both Jira and Confluence and no such error occurred.
fields.summary: Unable to migrate database to MySQL

fields.description:
It isn't possible to add Crowd users to local Stash groups.
We should definitely prevent this in the UI or provide a warning that it isn't possible.

Comment from customer:

bq. When trying to add a Crowd user, I click on the "Add user" button, and it just sits there... I see no errors (or new output) in the atlassian-stash.log file.
fields.summary: Prevent adding Crowd synced users to local groups in Stash

fields.description:
Request form customer:
bq. Each time a new version of Stash is released we are forced to refactor our RPM creation process to match the new release. Having an Atlassian-provided RPM for Stash would save us quite a bit of time and would increase our confidence in the final RPM that is used. I imagine that there are many other customers using package management tools that encounter the same issue as well.
fields.summary: Binary packages for Stash (e.g. RPM/deb)

fields.description:
If a developer has permissions to push on "branch1" but not on "branch2", when committing to both the whole push is denied. The error message shown is the following:
{noformat}
$ git push
...
Total 6 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
remote: You have insufficient permissions to update 'refs/heads/branch2'
remote: Check your branch permissions with the project administrator
To ....
 ! [remote rejected] branch1 -> branch1 (pre-receive hook declined)
 ! [remote rejected] branch2 -> branch2 (pre-receive hook declined)
error: failed to push some refs to ...
{noformat}
Ideally it should allow "half" of the push (in the branch where the developer has permissions). If that is not technically possible, perhaps a clearer message should be displayed.

In the case above it is easy to figure out why it is not possible to push. However, in a project with >100 developers, the permission maze would not allow to see why a push was denied. It also means that the developer will need to contact the administrator to check the permissions instead of getting notified what cannot be pushed.
fields.summary: Push Denied When Pushing to Multiple Branches With Different Permissions

fields.description:
Hi guys. When I run up a new instance of Stash using the Atlassian Plugin SDK, the commit hooks are not set up correctly. Is this pilot error, or is there something wrong with the start-up process?

Here's a listing of my hooks directory immediately after running {{atlas-mvn clean stash:debug}}:

{code}
drwxr-xr-x  14 dpinn  staff   476B  7 Dec 12:31 .
drwxr-xr-x   9 dpinn  staff   306B  7 Dec 12:31 ..
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   452B  5 Dec 13:12 applypatch-msg.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   896B  5 Dec 13:12 commit-msg.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   286B  5 Dec 13:12 post-receive
drwxr-xr-x   3 dpinn  staff   102B  7 Dec 12:31 post-receive.d
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   189B  5 Dec 13:12 post-update.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   398B  5 Dec 13:12 pre-applypatch.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   1.7K  5 Dec 13:12 pre-commit.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   4.8K  5 Dec 13:12 pre-rebase.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   285B  5 Dec 13:12 pre-receive
drwxr-xr-x   3 dpinn  staff   102B  7 Dec 12:31 pre-receive.d
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   1.2K  5 Dec 13:12 prepare-commit-msg.sample
-rw-r--r--   1 dpinn  staff   3.5K  5 Dec 13:12 update.sample
{code}

You can see that the post-receive hook, for example, lacks execute permissions. I'm not certain that it's the source of the problem, but {{GitHookUtils.installHookScriptFromClasspath}} is not checking the return value from {{File.setExecutable(true)}}.

The other little problem is that the hook-callback.pl file seems to have Windows line-endings. If I execute it from the command line, this happens:


{code}
git-hooks dpinn$ ./hook-callback.pl 
env: perl\r: No such file or directory
{code}

That problem goes away if I edit the file to turn the line endings into Unix flavour.
fields.summary: Commit hook permissions not set up correctly when starting stash from AMPS

fields.description:
h3. Symptoms

Stash fails to starts up properly on a 64-bit JVM on Windows with the following error:

{noformat}
tc-native-1.dll: Can't load IA 32-bit .dll on a AMD 64-bit platform
{noformat}


h3. Workaround:

If you're using a 64-bit JVM to run Stash, you'll need to replace tomcat.exe and tc-native-1.dll with their 64-bit versions. Stash ships both the 32-bit and the 64-bit versions of tomcat.exe and tc-native-1.dll:

* <STASH-INST>/bin/tomcat.exe - 32-bit
* <STASH-INST>/bin/tc-native-1.dll - 32-bit
* <STASH-INST>/bin/tomcat.exe.x64 - 64-bit
* <STASH-INST>/bin/tc-native-1.dll.x64 - 64-bit

To switch to the 64-bit versions, please do:

{noformat}
cd <STASH-INST/bin>
move tomcat.exe tomcat.exe.x86
move tc-native-1.dll tc-native-1.dll.x86
move tomcat.exe.x64 tomcat.exe
move tc-native-1.dll.x64 tc-native-1.dll
{noformat}

and start Stash
fields.summary: Tomcat fails to start up on 64-bit Windows with error tc-native-1.dll: Can't load IA 32-bit .dll
Pushing to Stash should not fail if the hook callback script fails to communicate back to the server

fields.description:
In stash 1.3, if you push a branch, and then (usually in response to the discussion) amend or rebase the branch, then push -f to updated, the pull request discussion shows added + removed commits.

However, there is no obvious way to compare the original state of the branch with then new branch to see what changed.
fields.summary: Diff between original commit and amended/rebased commit

fields.description: The discussion around a pull requests can be a valuable in understanding a commit.  There should be a quick way to get from the commit log for a branch to the pull requests that contributed to that log (a link next to each merge that is part of a pull request).
fields.summary: Show pull request links on the commit list

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

We spend a significant amount of time on an ongoing basis to determine our product investments in Bitbucket Server. Unfortunately, we are not currently planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last 12 months, we've resolved 10 of the top 30 feature requests, and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including in-browser editing, improvements to search functionality, better JIRA integration, and providing an even better code review experience.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but we believe it’s important for us to be open, honest and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original request description*

With stash 1.3, the description put into a pull requests only exists in the request.  This description should be put into the commit message.
fields.summary: Commit message for a merge pull request should include the title and description

fields.description:
The general pattern for our group is to work in a feature branch and pull into an integration branch, so typically there is only one commit in the branch.

Ideally, the title and description of the pull request would come directly from the commit message of this request, where title is the first line of the commmit (like git log --pretty=oneline).

Right now, our devs our copy/pasting the commit message into the request.

For multiple commits, it would be nice if there was a simple way make the description the equivalent of the commit message you would get from 'squash'.
fields.summary: Optimize workflow for pull requests when they have 1 commit

fields.description:
I just received an email stating that Stash is now offered in Enterprise tiers. This is clearly a mistake, since Stash isn't actually ready for enterprises. For instance, there is no SSO integration with Atlassian's own authentication solution (STASH-2493) and no way to have code accessed via normal, anonymous protocols (STASH-2565) like every other Git hosting solution on the planet.

Probably you should recall that email before more people notice this embarrassing mistake.
fields.summary: Stash Enterprise launched before Stash is enterprise ready

fields.description:
Context:
 * Windows XP Pro SP2
 * Git 1.7.9 installed with Cygwin
 * STASH_HOME=D:\stash_home

When trying to push, I have this error:
{code}
Counting objects: 17, done.
Delta compression using up to 2 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (9/9), done.
Writing objects: 100% (9/9), 1.32 KiB, done.
Total 9 (delta 5), reused 0 (delta 0)
remote: hooks/pre-receive: line 6: exec: D:\stash_home\bin\git-hooks\hook-coordinator.sh: not found
To ssh://git@git.domain.com:7999/PROJECT/repo.git
 ! [remote rejected] branch -> branch (pre-receive hook declined)
error: failed to push some refs to 'ssh://git.domain.com:7999/PROJECT/repo.git'
{code}

The path is MS-DOS and {{exec}} doesn't expand it and cannot find it in the PATH.
By changing {{/cygdrive/d/stash_home/data/repositories/1/hooks/pre-receive}} to change path to UNIX format, my problem is solved:
{code:language=bash}
#!/bin/bash
#>*******************************************************
# THIS FILE WAS AUTO-GENERATED BY ATLASSIAN STASH.
# DO NOT MODIFY UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE.
#>*******************************************************
exec $(cygpath "$STASH_HOOK_COORDINATOR") hooks/pre-receive.d "$@" <&0 >&1 2>&2
{code}
Idem for {{/cygdrive/d/stash_home/data/repositories/1/hooks/pre-receive.d/20_stash_callback}}, {{/cygdrive/d/stash_home/data/repositories/1/hooks/post-receive}} and {{/cygdrive/d/stash_home/data/repositories/1/hooks/post-receive.d/20_stash_callback}}

But I have to do it on every repository and it will be broken again on new repositories.
fields.summary: Hooks path error on Cygwin

fields.description:
On a large repository (20,000+ files), and about 100 commits, doing the following has strange behaviour:

*  Navigate to a project
*  Navigate to a repository
*  Click 'Commits'
*  Click on the first commit e.g '49774ce' for us in the commit column.
*  Press the back button in the browser (for us, Google Chrome 23.0.1271)

Now the Commits page is shown again, but the first commit we clicked on '49774ce' has disappeared (in fact the first couple of commits are missing for us), and all the commit links that are there are broken, taking me to the 404 skull'n'crossbones page.

This only seems to happen for certain repositories, and only ever when 'back' is clicked in the browser.

It is intermittent and I can't reproduce in a simple portable example.
fields.summary: Navigating back from specific commit to 'commits' page results in garbled commits

fields.description:
As a Stash user, I want to be able to associate a comment with multiple lines, not just a single line.

Currently, I can only associate a comment with a single line. Comments in code reviews are most of the time tied to multiple lines of code.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

There's definite interest in offering this functionality; the broader team have had quite a few conversations about it. Unfortunately, at the moment, there are significant technical challenges to overcome for server-side rebases to be viable. We have to keep instances that use pull requests heavily in mind, and the additional load of rebase operations is likely to significantly impact their scalability.

While it's unlikely that we'll be able to address this suggestion in the near future, we will continue to regularly consider how and when we might.

Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original request description*

As a Stash user, I would prefer to use a rebase workflow vs. a merge workflow for my Pull Requests.

This workflow permits to automatically obtain the following:
* When a PR is being merged:
** Condense (squash/rebase) all the commits in the source branch in a single one and leave that single commit on the branch
** Create a new merge commit on the target branch

So for every PR merged the expected outcome will be:
* One commit on the source branch containing *ALL* the changes made on the branch
* One commit on the target branch for the merge itself 

For more information on rebase workflows, please see:
* [A rebase-based workflow|http://unethicalblogger.com/2010/04/02/a-rebase-based-workflow.html]
* [A Rebase Workflow for Git|http://randyfay.com/content/rebase-workflow-git]
* [A Simple Git Rebase Workflow, Explained|http://mettadore.com/analysis/a-simple-git-rebase-workflow-explained/]
* [A Git Workflow for Agile Teams|http://reinh.com/blog/2009/03/02/a-git-workflow-for-agile-teams.html]
* [Our Git Workflow|http://brandonkonkle.com/blog/2010/apr/28/our-git-workflow/]

This is related to STASH-2873.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: As a Stash user I want to use a rebase workflow with Stash and for my Pull Requests

fields.description:
As a Stash User, prior to merging a Pull Request, I would like to rebase to master. 

Currently, when I do this directly against the git repo, I end up - following the merge - with duplicate commits shown against master.

As part of the Pull Request workflow, I should be able to rebase to master when creating the Pull Request, throughout the lifecycle of the Pull Request, and immediately prior to merging to master.

Historically, we have used a rebase vs. merge work flow. Stash is forcing us to change this workflow when it shouldn't.

This is related to STASH-2874.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: As a Stash user, I want to rebase prior to merging a Pull Request

fields.description:
As a Stash User, while reviewing a Pull Request, I want to be able to jump to the version of the file where a particular line changed.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: As a Stash user, in a Pull Request, I want to be able to jump to the version of the file where a particular line changed

fields.description:
As a Stash User, I want to be able to see the History of a File when reviewing a Pull Request. 

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: As a Stash user, I want to see a file's history in the context of a Pull Request

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of May 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for your feedback and advocacy on this suggestion. [Bitbucket Data Center 7.13|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-data-center-and-server-7-13-release-notes-1056675425.html#BitbucketDataCenterandServer7.13releasenotes-groupsReviewergroupsforpullrequests] introduces *Reviewer groups* that allow you to add a group of users as reviewers when creating a Pull request. Project and repository admins will be able to create and manage these groups making it easier for development teams to self-manage. You can read more details [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/reviewer-groups-for-pull-requests-1064084872.html].  

Please give it a try and let us know your feedback in a comment below.

Cheers,
Carla Baba
Software developer - Bitbucket Data Center
{panel}
*Original request description*

In our workflow, any member of a team may comment on or approve most code reviews. With our previous code review systems (ReviewBoard, then gerrit) we could just add a mailing list or group to the 'Reviewer' list and this would notify all the team. However, with stash pull requests, each user needs to be added manually, which is tedious and error prone for more then a few users.
fields.summary: Add a group to "pull request" reviewers

fields.summary: Cmd/Ctrl+Return doesn't submit comment when in preview

fields.description:
When you are using JIRA for authentication and you make a user 'inactive' in JIRA, they are still displayed in Stash and appear to be active.

Making a user inactive in JIRA should make them inactive in any application using JIRA for authentication.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: When using JIRA authentication, inactive users are shown in Stash

fields.description:
As a Stash User, I want to be able to specify the amount of 'context' provided for a diff in a Pull Request.

Specifically, as I can in Fisheye/Crucible, I should be able to have the entire file as my context and be able to comment on it.

While the "View Full Source of This File" option is available, it only allows file viewing. I cannot comment on the full file and have those comments be reflected in the Pull Request.

This morning, several users who have been enthusiastic about moving from Crucible to Stash, told me, "I had to go and create a code review in Crucible to see what I wanted to see and provide appropriate comments."

The code review and diff functionality provided in Stash is a bit simplistic compared to that available in Fisheye. The goal should make the functionality and tools available for code reviews equal to that in Fisheye.

The lack of code review and diff functionality is forcing our users of Stash to either create code reviews in Fisheye/Crucible or to use the git command line tools to understand what they are reviewing and its impact.

This is related to STASH-2871 and STASH-2872.

Jordan Dea-Mattson
fields.summary: As a Stash User, I want to be able to specify the amount of 'context' provided for a diff
Adds additional logging for the changeset indexing

fields.description:
Due to a [bug in active objects|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AO-386] running on Microsoft SQL Server the columns used to store String values can't cope with non-ASCII characters. 

This means that branch permissions with non-ASCII characters in branch names, pattern values and group names may not behave as expected when running on MSSQL.
fields.summary: Non-ASCII values used in branch permissions don't work in MSSQL

fields.description:
In an attempt to limit write access to master branch, I added a pre-receive hook into my server side repo. This works fine for pushes being done from Git command line.

However, when someone opens a PR for master branch and merges them, the pre-receive hook is not run, thus granting write-access to all.
fields.summary: Pre-receive hooks don't run when merging a pull-request

fields.description: For security reason, I want to let the administrator to review all ssh-keys added by users.This can prevent password-leaking and invalid ssh-key be added. See this:  STASH-2859 - disable http clone
fields.summary: User add ssh key should be review by administrator

fields.description:
Can I config stash to disable http clone?
b/c I didn't config https support successfully, so I want to disable http clone for security.
fields.summary: Allow disabling of Git operations over HTTP

fields.description: The 500 error message shows instead of the 'proper' error message. For more, please refer to the following knowledge base article: [OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM is an unsupported JVM|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4c5Eg]
fields.summary: Tomcat 500 error when runs on the OpenJDK

fields.description:
The merge button on pull request does "git merge -no-ff".
This is highly undesirable as it gives a bushy history line for no good reason. 

As it is not configurable at the moment, at least it should simply call "git merge" which allow fast forwards.

Better yet merge behaviour and strategy should be configurable for the repository with the same default as "git merge" itself. 
And/or even allow these options for each pull request merge.

With STASH-2810 and STASH-2753, this would make Pull Requests totally rocks.
fields.summary: Pull Request should not force --no-ff flag

fields.description:
Currently, Stash raises {{ProjectDeletedRequestedEvent}} and {{RepositoryDeleteRequestedEvent}} to allow plugins to perform cleanup when projects and repositories are deleted. It would be useful to raise similar events when a project or repository is being created.

Additionally, the existing events do not allow plugins to prevent projects or repositories from being deleted. Any exceptions they throw are caught, logged and swallowed by Atlassian Events. It could be very useful, especially for the new creation events, to allow plugins to cancel the operation and provide an explanation which would then be relayed back to the caller.
fields.summary: Add project and repository creation requested events

fields.description:
With a large pull request (lots of diffs), you have to keep scrolling down over and over to load everything before you can page search for a specific file or reference. (BTW- I know that the recommendation is to not have a lot of files in a single pull request, but sometimes it happens.)

It would be nice to have some way to be able to load the entire page at once so that you could use the browser's search (cmd-F) to find text on the page. While I applaud the attempt to load the page quickly, sometimes it isn't desired.
fields.summary: Provide a way to load all diffs in a pull request at once to be able to search page for text

fields.description:
Hi :)

The current stash does not display any feeds into the "Activity Stream".

Activity Stream is seen when u click on a project in Jira.

The minimal level of reporting from Stash would be at least to report a commit into the "Activity Stream" of the project, and would be nice if u can do that in the "Notifications" area as well.

This feature should be a quick win into further integration for Stash, please let us know when can we expect to see that.

You must know that you have great products, but you need to unleash its power through cross-app communications.

You also should add further integration into the Source tab, please check the attached Shot.

I look forward to hear from your great team.

Please think of this in the way that Developers want to see their achievement broadcasted, it is a motivation tool, and it is a reporting mechanics that servers teams and coordination.

Best regards,
RA
fields.summary: Stash --> Jira Activities/Notifications missing from Project "Activity Stream"

fields.description:
Scrolling in the Pull request->diff page is really anoying. 

if the diff is long, the treeview height follows the page height, and if you scroll the page the treeview scross yoo. In this way you loose the treeview current item, and you need to scroll back to the top to return to the currently selected item.
In addition, if I then click to a different (larger or shorter) item, I easily loose track of the current treeview item.

Ideally, the treeview should be of fixed height(maybe the browser page height), and the diff content should scroll in an independent way from the treeview.
fields.summary: Improved diff window scrolling

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Imran Khan

Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

Show activity across repositories in Stash.
fields.summary: Cross repository activity stream

fields.description:
*Original request description:*

h5. Problem
Stash currently supports searching for specific files, not code and not across multiple repositories.

h5. Suggested solution
Extending this to also search for code within a single or across multiple repositories would be a great addition. 

h5. Workaround
You can try using one of the following solutions:
- https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/eu.solumiss.stash.search.solumiss-stash-search-plugin
- https://github.com/google/codesearch
- https://github.com/palantir/stash-codesearch-plugin

Please note that the above are not Atlassian developed plugins, so use them at your own risk.
fields.summary: Code search

fields.description:
I don't know when 1.4 is getting released, but here are some features I'd like to see in a future version (or extra plugins):

*  Code search
*  Activity feed across repositories on the home page
**  Even if it is just an aggregation of user commits.
*  Automatic repository forking within Stash, either within, or across projects (and not limited to '1 fork per repo' per user like github is).
**  I appreciate we can do this manually, by clone/create/push, but doing it in the browser would be nicer.
**  This could be displayed hierarchically (e.g. see Hg Kiln and 'branch repositories')
*  Diffs between different changesets rather than just the previous one

Otherwise, Stash is a good solid offering so far!

Remember branch when switching tab

Pull Requests are pretty lightweight.

fields.description:
Currently, the date of a commit is shown in relative terms (i.e. "last week", "two hours ago". When comparing to log messages in other systems, you want to get an absolute date (Friday, March 1 at 21:06 PST).

Please make this an option.
fields.summary: Give option to display absolute vs. relative date in views

fields.description:
It should be possible to send a notification when someone does a pull request. 

We work with a model where only a few team members may merge to the stable master branch. They should be notified when another team member has a new pull request that should be looked into.
This seems not supported now, although notifications on activity on the pull request is supported.
fields.summary: New pull request notification
Improve Postgres integration guide to include pg_hba.conf related configuration

fields.description: Need an intuitive way of getting a link to the section including a diff and comments in the pull request screen. When you have a large pull request containing hundreds of diffs and want to IM about a specific diff, have no way of linking to target of specific diff. Can't just use the built-in commenting functionality because notifications are unfriendly to non-threaded-email notifications in a situation with lots of files in a pull request and lots of comments (STASH-2839). Please add a share link that maybe unhides a div containing a small area containing the shortened URL (and perhaps provide Jabber, etc. support to share) or just a link to target that part of the page. Thanks.
fields.summary: Add the ability to Share pull requests

fields.description: Triggering builds (including branch builds) on a push instead of using a polling strategy
fields.summary: Trigger bamboo builds when there are new commits on associated branches

fields.description:
Hi mates.

A customer asked for the following:

{quote}Stash does not currently have any support for JMX counters. The REST API only exposes very basic statistics and isn't adequate for our monitoring needs. We'd like to request that Stash be instrumented with JMX counters for the following:

* Total number of projects
* Total number of repositories
* Git pushes and pulls
* Source code size on disk (ideally broken down on the per-project or per-repo basis)
* Event queue size
* Any other relevant metrics that can possibly be included
{quote}

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Addition of Stash JMX Counters
